title: Configure OAuth authentication with Azure AD for OO Workflow Designer
content:
​

This topic describes the steps to configure Open Authentication (OAuth) with Azure Active Directory for Operations Orchestration (OO) Workflow Designer. 

OAuth authentication with Azure Active Directory

OAuth authentication enables applications to obtain limited access to user accounts on the OO Workflow Designer portal. OO Workflow Designer uses Microsoft Azure as the OAuth-based identity authentication protocol to verify the identity of an end user.

Apply for the client Id and client secret in the Azure AD portal

To apply for the client Id and client secret:

  1. Log in to the Azure portal.
  2. From the listed Azure Services, click Azure Active Directory. An overview page of the Azure Active directory displays.
  3. Perform the following steps to register the OO Workflow Designer web application, if not already done:
    1. Select App registrations, then select New Registration. The Register an application form appears.
    2. In the Name field, enter the display name of your application. For example, OOWorkflowDesigner.
    3. In the Redirect URI (Optional) field, enter the Redirect URL that's generated automatically, when creating OAuth authentication in the OO Workflow Designer IdM Administration console.

      The following image is from the OO Workflow Designer IdM Administration console.
    4. Click Register. The application registration is successful. Record the Application (client) ID for use in a later step.
  4. To access the OO Workflow Designer application, generate client secrets using the following steps:
    1. In the left menu, under Manage, select Certificates and secrets. 
    2. Select New Client Secret.
    3. Enter the client secret description. For example, oocentralsecret.
    4. Click Add. The values of the client secret get generated.

      Important

      The generated client secret is important for configuration in the IdM administration console.

  5. To view and make a note of the endpoints:
    1. Select App registrations.
    2. Select your application to open its Overview page.
    3. Click Endpoints to record the Application (client) ID and OpenID Connect metadata document URL from the list shown in the Endpoints window. 

      Important

      Make a note of the client secret value generated in step 4d.

Create an OAuth in IdM administration console for OO Workflow Designer

To create an OAuth consent to access the OO Workflow Designer, perform the following steps:

  1. Create an OAuth authentication.
    1. From OO Workflow Designer> IdM Administration Console, click the organization. Click Authentication >   , choose OAUTH as the authentication type, and then click CREATE.
    2. Enter the valid values for Name, Display Name, Client Id, and Client Secret.
    3. Choose an Authorization Mode from the drop-down and an Http Method.
    4. Enter the following fields:
      1. IDP URL: Use the Open Connect metadata document URL displayed in the Endpoints window of Azure AD.
      2. Redirect URI: Use the default redirect URI.
      3. Scope: Use the default value.
    5. Select State Supported, if supported, and enter valid values to the following fields:
      1. Username Attribute: Use the default value. For example, sub.
      2. Userinfo Endpoint: Enter the Userinfo Endpoint data that's retrieved using the following steps:
        1. Copy and paste the complete OpenID Connect metadata document URL in your browser.
        2. Find and use the userinfo_endpoint parameter for the Userinfo Endpoint field.
      3. Token Endpoint: Use the default value. For example, /token
      4. Authorization Endpoint: Use the default value. For example, /authorize
      5. Logout Endpoint: The redirect URI that you wish to see after you log out of the application. For example,  /logout?post_logout_redirect_uri=<https://<FQDN or IP of Workflow Designer>:<PORT>/idm-admin/>
      6. Additional Parameter: The additional parameter for Azure authentication.
        The table below lists the detailed descriptions of the related OAuth settings:
        Field Required Description
        Display Name true The display name of this configuration.
        Client Id true The value of Client Id that you get from the Azure Active Directory identity provider.
        Client Secret true The value of Client Secret that you get from the Azure Active Directory identity provider.
        Http Method true The Http method of getting the user's information from the endpoint. The supported values are GET and POST.
        IDP URL true The endpoint or URL path provided by the Azure Active Directory Identity Provider. The URL set for "Redirect URI" that's directed to the Identity Protocol (IDP) URL.
        Redirect URI true The value of redirect URI of the IDP URL to log into the OO Workflow Designer portal.
        Scope true The value of scope. For example, "azure email."
        State Supported false Whether support the State Supported feature. The supported values are "false" and "true''.
        Username Attribute true The attribute to define a username.
        User Info Endpoint true An OAuth Protected Resource that returns Claims about the authenticated end user. For example, https://graph.microsoft.com/oidc/userinfo.
        Token Endpoint true The token endpoint of the Azure identity provider. The Token Endpoint used to obtain a Token Response. For example, /token.
        Authentication Endpoint true The Authorization Endpoint performs authentication of the end user by sending the user agent to the authorization server's endpoint for authentication and authorization, using request parameters defined by OAuth and additional parameters and parameter values defined by Azure. For example, /authorize.
        Logout Endpoint false The logout request that's sent to Azure to log out from Azure Active Directory and the application. 
        Additional Parameter false The additional parameter for authentication.
  2. Click SAVE.

Set up OAuth Authentication with Azure AD access tokens using REST API

The following image is a graphical representation of the process involved.

Note

Read the OO Server in the image as the OO Workflow Designer Server.

To set up OAuth-based authentication with Azure AD, complete the following prerequisites:

  1. Register the following two applications:

    1. OO Workflow Designer Server: The server contains the roles that the  IdM service will use for Role Based Access Control (RBAC).
    2. Client application: The client application will use the OO Workflow Designer server using Azure access tokens.
  2. Select the registered OO Workflow Designer Server application and then click Expose an API blade to add the Client application and scope. This allows the Client application to access the OO Workflow Designer Server.
  3. Select the registered Client application and click the API permissions blade to add permissions to the user. For example, access_as_user
  4. Use Azure AD On behalf of flow to make the following POST and GET calls.

Retrieve the access ID from the client application

Run the Azure On Behalf Of Flow (OBOF) password flow. Highlighted are client_id/client_secret of client app registration.
